Trade

Other News
- US President Trump said Singapore Summit with North Korea's Kim will not take place and that it is inappropriate to have the planned summit at this time. Trump added the cancelled summit with Kim was "based on the tremendous anger and open hostility" in Kim's statement. (Newswires)
- US President Trump said US is ready if necessary to counter any North Korean threat and that a maximum pressure campaign on North Korea will continue. However, President Trump added that it is possible that the existing summit with North Korea could take place at a later date, while White House official said back channels for discussions with North Korea are still open, but the rhetoric must change from North Korea's side. (KCNA)

- BoK are to hold a meeting to discuss US-North Korea summit situation. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China is said to plan to cut tariffs on consumer goods, effective July 1st; this ranges from cosmetics to food. (Newswires)


UK

BoE Governor Carney said BOE could tolerate a lengthier inflation overshoot up to a point and endorses a gradual path of hikes but added that it can be accelerated if growth rises above 1.5% trend rate and business investment recovers strongly. Carney also commented that Brexit is entering a ‘critical phase’ and BoE has tools to deal with all outcomes, while he added that BoE could take steps as it did after the Brexit referendum If the process becomes disorderly. (Newswires)

BoE's Ramsden said is comfortable that Q1 slowdown was temporary and looks for gently increasing rates over the forecast horizon

UK Chancellor Hammond said both Brexit customs models are work in progress, while there were also comments from an official that UK PM May's war cabinet remains stalled on customs union options. (Newswires)

UK Government source denied reports suggesting UK PM May was to ask the EU for a new transition period until 2023 and said that this remains at December 2020. There were also comments from an EU official that there weren’t any discussions regarding a longer transition period nor the Irish border issue. (Newswires)

UK Retail Sales MM (Apr) 1.6% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. -1.2%, Rev. -1.1%)
UK Retail Sales YY (Apr) 1.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 1.1%, Rev. 1.3%)


EU

ECB minutes stated that the more pronounced weakening of demand cannot be ruled out, while it added that uncertainty of outlook has increased and that the slowdown is broad-based. Furthermore, a view was expressed that the ECB was close to a sustained adjustment of inflation but most disagreed. (Newswires)

A source close to the Italian President stated that Conte's choice of ministers is considered unacceptable by Mattarella. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

WTI extended losses on Thursday as risk-off sentiment lingered, and losses were exacerbated after US President Trump cancelled the summit with North Korea’s Kim; traders also continue to cite the surprise inventory build in the week. Additionally, OPEC’s intent to to offset supply disruptions caused by Iran and Venezuela, perhaps by boosting oil output for some producers, remained on traders’ minds. Russian Energy Minister Novak on Thursday said OPEC+ participants are planning to keep the production deal in place for now, specifying that restrictions on oil production could be eased "softly" if OPEC+ sees oil market balance in June, where gradual oil output recovery will be discussed. Novak currently sees the average oil price at more than USD 60/bbl, and also said Russia is of similar mind with Saudi Arabia on oil output. That wasn’t the view of Russian oil producer Lukoil, which believes now is the right time to boost production. Elsewhere, Eastern Libyan oil company AGOCO raised its output to 180k BPD (vs 146k bpd on Wednesday).

Venezuela President Maduro vowed to raise oil production. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said the global oil glut is finished. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said Singapore Summit with North Korea's Kim will not take place and that it is inappropriate to have the planned summit at this time. Trump added the cancelled summit with Kim was "based on the tremendous anger and open hostility" in Kim's statement. (Newswires)

US President Trump said US is ready if necessary to counter any North Korean threat and that a maximum pressure campaign on North Korea will continue. However, President Trump added that it is possible that the existing summit with North Korea could take place at a later date, while White House official said back channels for discussions with North Korea are still open, but the rhetoric must change from North Korea's side. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said preparations are well under way for further sanctions on Iran and that he hopes that they will be backed by the UN and other nations. (Newswires)

French President Macron stressed he does not want to renegotiate the Iran nuclear deal and that he sees possible talks to complement the deal but not replace it. (Newswires)
 

US

Mexico reportedly made US an offer in a bid to reach a NAFTA agreement. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said US move on possible auto tariffs is 'on even flimsier logical ground than argument in favour of steel and aluminium tariffs' and that the US auto tariffs are clearly linked to NAFTA talks. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dovish) said he sees 3 rate hikes this year and 3 rate hikes next year, while he added that he may be open to a fourth hike in 2018 if inflation accelerates and that the Fed is getting closer to neutral rate. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said he is comfortable with 3 rate hikes in 2018 and that he sees the neutral rate at around 2.25% to 2.75%. (Newswires)

US Existing Home Sales (Apr) 5.46M vs. Exp. 5.56M (Prev. 5.60M). (Newswires)
US Existing Home Sales % Change (Apr) -2.5% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. 1.1%)


MARKET RECAP

US equity futures continue to shrug-off news flow, and the thin range seen in ES this week continued on Thursday ahead of the Memorial Day long weekend. The 2720-2730 range was prevalent premarket, and after the cash day got underway, news Trump pulled out from the North Korea peace summit in June brought a risk-off tone, sending ES to test 2705 once again; however, later in the session, Trump gave more colour and floated the possibility that a summit could take place at a later day, if North Korea’s rhetoric was to become more constructive. ES resumed its drift upwards into the range, moving back into the range of the weekly horizontal drift. In sectors, energy lagged on the back of lower oil prices immediately followed by financials, which took a hit amid the broad-based risk-off tone and a flattening yield curve. Utility and telecom held in positive territory as defence sectors. SPX -0.2% at 2727, NDX -0.1% at 6949, DJI -0.3% at 24812.

Treasuries edged higher in the session amid growing geopolitical tensions between North Korea and the US which deteriorated risk sentiment and pushed investors into safe havens. The yield curve bull-flattened with most of the buying action focused in the long end of the curve, where 10yr and 30yr yields were down by c.2bps at settlement, seeing 5s30s and 10s30s narrow by c.1bps. The Treasury auctioned 30bln in 7yr notes, stopping-through by 0.5bps at a high yield of 2.930%. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.62 the highest since January. 65.5% was awarded to indirects, dealers took 21.6% whilst directs saw the biggest share since February, just under 13%. Overall the auction was well-received given the strong internals. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 16+ ticks higher at 119-15+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 24 May 2018: Trump pulls out of North Korea summit
content:
US MARKET WRAP 24 May 2018: Trump pulls out of North Korea summit

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, DXY down, Crude down.
* REAR-VIEW: Boring ECB minutes, BoE's Carney warns on Brexit again, Little new in Fedspeak.
* AHEAD: Earnings from ADSK, ROST, DXC after-market; Japanese Tokyo CPI overnight; German IFO, UK GDP, US Durables, more BoE Carney, ECB's Coeure & Liikanen and multiple Fed's speak including Powell on Friday.

* NORTH KOREA: US President Trump pulled out of the 12 June summit with North Korea leader Kim, adding that the meeting is inappropriate at this time due to the “tremendous anger and open hostility displayed in [Kim’s] most recent statement.” Trump, however, said that he looks very much forward to meeting Kim some day; A White House official later said that back channels for discussions with North Korea remain open, but North Korean rhetoric must change. Separately, a US official suggested further sanctions could be place on North Korea perhaps as soon as next week.

* IRAN: US Secretary of State Pompeo says preparations are well under way for further sanctions on Iran, and he hopes that they will be backed by the UN and other nations. Pompeo also again said that regime change was not the US objective. Earlier, Russia’s Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia will work with Iran, despite possible US sanctions. And the IAEA again said that Iran has stayed within the limits of uranium enrichment outlined in the 2015 nuclear deal. France President Macron stressed he does not want to renegotiate the Iran nuclear deal; he possible talks to completeness the deal, but not replace it

* TRADE: with the exception of Ford and General Motors, auto stocks were getting slammed after yesterday’s aftermarket report that the Trump administration was mulling 25% auto tariffs. The decision news has caused some angst even among Republican lawmakers; Senate Finance Committee Chair Hatch says possible US auto tariffs are “deeply misguided”. On NAFTA, Canada's Trudeau said US move on possible auto tariffs “on even flimsier logical ground than argument in favour of steel and aluminium tariffs”, and that the US auto tariffs are clearly linked to NAFTA talks. Trudeau noted there is a long way to go before the US actually sets tariffs on autos.

* BREXIT: Following reports that UK PM May was to ask EU for an Brexit transition period extension through 2023 in order to avoid a hard Irish border, a UK government source denied the report, and said this proposed exit remains end-2020. Separately, the UK Chancellor Hammond said the UK wants a partnership with the EU on financial services, and on the model of Brexit, said both Brexit customs models are a work in process. Elsewhere, an EU official said there was no discussion of the Irish border issue at the Eurogroup meeting today; Irish officials in parliament continue to demand details.

* BOE SPEAK: BOE Governor Carney said that Brexit is entering a ‘critical phase’, BOE has tools to deal with all outcomes; if the process becomes disorderly, BOE could take steps as it did after the Brexit referendum. On rate hikes, Carney again endorsed a gradual path, but said it could be accelerated if growth rises above the trend rate, and if business investment recovers more strongly. Carney again said Q1 weakness was likely temporary, but uncertainty around consumer spending is somewhat greater now due to slower lending and spending, as well as the housing market. Carney also said that the BOE could tolerate a lengthier inflation overshoot, up to a point. BOE deputy governor Ramsden said he is comfortable that Q1 slowdown was temporary and looks for gently increasing rates over the forecast horizon. BOE governor Carney gave some comments in the morning but veered away from monetary policy and the economic outlook.

* FEDSPEAK: Although there was a lot of Fedspeak on the docket today, there was little for traders to sink their teeth into, with the likes of Fed’s Dudley (outgoing NY Fed President) staying away from monetary policy comments. The almost ever-present Bostic (voter, dovish) again said he was in the three hikes camp, and sees the neutral rate between 2.25% and 2.75%. Fed’s Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) sees the FOMC lifting rates another four rate times before ending the hiking cycle and reaches neutral levels, and added that inflation could run at a rate above 2% for a bit before the Fed takes action. Fed's Harker (non-voter, dovish) sees 3 rate hikes this year and 3 rate hikes next year, but would be open to a fourth 2018 hike if inflation accelerates. He also said the Fed is getting closer to neutral rate, and sees the Fed ending the hiking cycle in 2019. The NY Fed Primary Dealer Survey was also released and anticipated three more rate hikes this year.

* ECB MINUTES: The account of the ECB’s meeting saw members agree that the more pronounced weakening of demand cannot be ruled out, and noted that uncertainty of outlook has increased, with the slowdown remaining broad-based. The Council agreed that inflation will gradually reach the desired target. A view that the ECB is close to a sustained adjustment of inflation was also expressed but most disagreed. There was barely any immediate market reaction to the minutes. Note that at the post-meeting press conference, President Draghi said that the ECB discussed little directly on monetary policy “per se”, and that seems to be reflected in the minutes, and accordingly, the market reaction. The main takeaways of the meeting indicate the ECB is unlikely to change tone in June and strengthen the view that the ECB will wait until July to announce its QE plan, Capital Economics said..

* ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Praet says economic conditions are good despite clouds, and that the slowdown in economic indicators reflects supply constraints, though he did concede that there may be a more fundamental problem of confidence. ECB's Vasiliauskas said that he doesn't disagree with forecasts of ECB rate hike in six months.

* SARB: The South Africa Reserve Bank kept both its Prime Rate and Report Rate unchanged at 10.00% and 6.50% respectively, in line with expectations. The tone was fairly hawkish, with the Governor stating that inflation pressures had bottomed-out, and price pressures would firm in the months ahead driven by higher fuel prices.

* DATA: US Jobless Claims came in at 234k beating the consensus at 220k, though revised lower to 223k. The rebound suggests that prior figures around 210k was led by seasonal adjustments. Nonetheless, analysts at Pantheon still see the underlying trend edging lower towards the 220k mark. US Existing Home Sales edged lower to 5.46mln missing expectations at 5.56mln mostly attributed to a fall in re-sale of single family homes which fell by 3% and an absence of inventories. Wells Fargo noted that despite the decline in sales, demand remains strong and prices continue to be sustained, though higher prices and rising interest rates will be determining the strength of buyers’ demand.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.2% at 2727, NDX -0.1% at 6949, DJI -0.3% at 24812.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.1%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: 0.2%, Energy: -1.7%, Financials: -0.7%, Health Care: -0.3%, Industrials: 0.6%, Materials: -0.4%, Telecom: 0.6%, Tech: -0.1%, Utilities: 0.8%

US equity futures continue to shrug-off news flow, and the thin range seen in ES this week continued on Thursday ahead of the Memorial Day long weekend. The 2720-2730 range was prevalent premarket, and after the cash day got underway, news Trump pulled out from the North Korea peace summit in June brought a risk-off tone, sending ES to test 2705 once again; however, later in the session, Trump gave more colour and floated the possibility that a summit could take place at a later day, if North Korea’s rhetoric was to become more constructive. ES resumed its drift upwards into the range, moving back into the range of the weekly horizontal drift.

In sectors, energy lagged on the back of lower oil prices immediately followed by financials, which took a hit amid the broad-based risk-off tone and a flattening yield curve. Utility and telecom held in positive territory as defence sectors.

In earnings, L Brands (LB) was one of the top performers on the S&P after reporting its numbers, despite a slight miss on EPS; whereas BestBuy (BBY) and Hormel Food (HRL) suffered losses above 7% and were the worst performers in the index, the former after cutting its EPS guidance and the latter after reporting a miss on both top and bottom line.

In equity specific stories, General Electric (GE) was boosted following reports from CNBC’s Faber’s suggesting the co. is not looking to cut its dividend again. Celgene (CELG) also printed gains on the back of its USD 3bln repurchase programme announcement.

In M&A news, activist investor Chris Hohn insisted that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) engaged with Comcast (CMCSA) if it is to make a better offer than Disney (DIS) which was at USD 52bln.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle USD 1.13 lower at USD 70.71/bbl, Brent futures settle USD 1.01 lower at USD 78.79/bbl. WTI extended losses on Thursday as risk-off sentiment lingered, and losses were exacerbated after US President Trump cancelled the summit with North Korea’s Kim; traders also continue to cite the surprise inventory build in the week. Additionally, OPEC’s intent to to offset supply disruptions caused by Iran and Venezuela, perhaps by boosting oil output for some producers, remained on traders’ minds. Russian Energy Minister Novak on Thursday said OPEC+ participants are planning to keep the production deal in place for now, specifying that restrictions on oil production could be eased "softly" if OPEC+ sees oil market balance in June, where gradual oil output recovery will be discussed. Novak currently sees the average oil price at more than USD 60/bbl, and also said Russia is of similar mind with Saudi Arabia on oil output. That wasn’t the view of Russian oil producer Lukoil, which believes now is the right time to boost production. Elsewhere, Eastern Libyan oil company AGOCO raised its output to 180k BPD (vs 146k bpd on Wednesday).

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 16+ ticks higher at 119-15+. Treasuries edged higher in the session amid growing geopolitical tensions between North Korea and the US which deteriorated risk sentiment and pushed investors into safe havens. The yield curve bull-flattened with most of the buying action focused in the long end of the curve, where 10yr and 30yr yields were down by c.2bps at settlement, seeing 5s30s and 10s30s narrow by c.1bps. The Treasury auctioned 30bln in 7yr notes, stopping-through by 0.5bps at a high yield of 2.930%. The bid-to-cover came in at 2.62 the highest since January. 65.5% was awarded to indirects, dealers took 21.6% whilst directs saw the biggest share since February, just under 13%. Overall the auction was well-received given the strong internals.

* COMING UP: Japanese Tokyo CPI. Expectations are for headline CPI to stay at 0.5% and ex-fresh food and energy at 0.3%. Core consumer goods inflation tumbled from 0.8% the previous month and Capital Economics expect the recent moderation in producer prices to keep consumer goods inflation subdued, although rising labour costs means service inflation could push higher.

Daily FX Wrap: USD/JPY slips as Donald rejects Kim. GBP gains short-lived. Market doesn’t buy CBRT rate hike. ECB Mins suggest bank could wait until July
content:
FX markets initially traded in a more relaxed fashion compared to yesterday’s sizeable moves with most majors stuck to their recent ranges in the first half of trade with the USD back below 94.00 in the wake of yesterday’s FOMC minutes. However, the final stages of trade saw the greatest bout of volatility for the session after news that US President Trump withdrew from peace talks with North Korea which saw USD/JPY break below the earlier low of 109.34 and the 30DMA at 109.20 before stopping short of testing 109.00 to the downside.

Elsewhere, the EUR was granted some reprieve by the softer USD with EUR/USD reclaiming the 1.1700 handle after yesterday’s data-inspired rout with today’s ECB minutes offering very little in the way of new information for traders other than the Bank wishing to see as much data as possible before curtailing bonds purchases. Capital Economics subsequently view July as a more opportune time for Draghi and Co. to announce their decision to taper its purchases to zero over the final three months of the year. In terms of prospects for downside in EUR/USD setback are said to be well supported ahead of the 1.1600 level.

GBP/USD initially reclaimed 1.3400 to the upside after an across the board beat for UK retail sales, allied with upward revisions for 3/4 metrics. However, the support for GBP was relatively short-lived as focus turned to tomorrow’s secondary Q1 GDP reading and Brexit related rhetoric amid mixed messages once again coming from UK press and the government after government sources denied reports suggesting UK PM May was to ask the EU for a new transition period until 2023.

Finally, the TRY pared a bulk of its gains seen against the USD yesterday after the CBRT held an extraordinary meeting to evaluate recent developments in which it raised the Late Liquidity Window (the lending rate) by 300bps to 16.50%, while it added that it will use strong monetary tightening to support price stability. Given the price action in recent trade, it appears that markets still cast serious doubts over the autonomy of the CBRT and whether attempts to defy Erdogan will be sustainable in the long-term ahead of domestic elections next month.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European auto names are hit by the US import probe
  • WTI crude (-0.7%) and Brent (-0.8%) continue to extend losses
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB minutes and speakers include: Fed’s Bostic, Kaplan, Harker, and BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded subdued with Trump’s trade policies returning to the forefront of attention after the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232, while reports also noted that tariffs of as much as 25% are being considered and is likely an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal. In addition, increasing uncertainty whether the US-North Korea summit will take place added to dampened tone, which in turn has collectively overshadowed a slightly-dovish perceived FOMC minutes. Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) was the underperformer as currency strength sapped exporter sentiment and with automakers reeling from the prospects of the hefty import duties, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) was led lower by financials amid the ongoing banking royal commission grilling on the sector, although broader losses in the index were stemmed by strength in consumer stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) and Hang Seng (+0.3) traded indecisive following a net neutral liquidity operation by the PBoC and mixed signals on trade talks from President Trump who stated discussions are moving along nicely, but then suggested a change in the structure may be needed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the underperformance seen in Japanese stocks, as prices took a breather from the prior day’s gains and with weaker demand seen in today’s enhanced-liquidity auction for 10yr-30yr JGBs.

China Mofcom said it will encourage companies to import more from US and that it welcomes US sending officials to China, although it reiterated that China has not promised to reduce trade deficit by a certain amount and will unswervingly protect its interests. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3816 (Prev. 6.3773)

Bank of Korea kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected, via unanimous decision. BoK stated that domestic growth is on foreseen path and that exports will sustain expansion, but also noted job growth slowed and that growth of household debt has exceeded the pace seen in past years. (Newswires)

New Zealand Trade Balance (Apr) M/M 263.0M vs. Exp. 198.0M (Prev. -86.0M, Rev. -156.0M). (Newswires)

New Zealand Exports (Apr) 5.05B vs. Exp. 4.85B (Prev. 4.85B, Rev. 4.79B)

New Zealand Imports (Apr) 4.79B vs. Exp. 4.65B (Prev. 4.94B, Rev. 4.95B)

TRADE

China is said to plan to cut tariffs on consumer goods, effective July 1st; this ranges from cosmetics to food. (Newswires)

US President Trump instructed the Commerce Department to consider Section 232 trade investigation on auto imports for national security purposes, while reports also noted that the Trump administration is considering a plan that would impose new tariffs of as much as 25% on imported vehicles. (Newswires/WSJ)

Mexico NAFTA negotiator said a skinny NAFTA deal is not an option and that they are not interested in a partial agreement. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Italy's 5 Star is considering Zingales for Finance Minister, some see him as more of a mainstream candidate. (Newswires/ANSA) Forza Italia's Berlusconi says he cannot support a 5 Star/League government. (Newswires)

The Times reported UK PM May is to ask EU for a new Brexit transition to last until 2023 to avoid a hard border. This was then dismissed by dismissed by government sources. (Times/Newswires)

UK Retail Sales MM (Apr) 1.6% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. -1.2%, Rev. -1.1%)

UK Retail Sales YY (Apr) 1.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 1.1%, Rev. 1.3%)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he will know by next week if the summit with North Korea on June 12th will go ahead. In related news, North Korea said it condemns comments from US Vice-President Pence that North Korea may end up like Libya, while a Foreign Ministry official stated they will suggest to North Korea’s leadership to reconsider summit and that summit is entirely up to Washington. (Nikkei/KCNA)

North Korea has demolished its nuclear test site in Punggye-ri. (Yonhap)

US Ambassador to Israel said the White House Middle East peace plan could be unveiled within next few months. (Newswires)

US expelled 2 Venezuelan diplomats in which they were ordered to leave in 48 hours. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Praet says economic conditions are good despite clouds. (Newswires)

ECB's Vasiliauskas doesn't disagree with ECB's rate hike forecasts in six months. (Newswires)

Russian central bank chief says they are unlikely to raise rates adding that there is room to cut rates to neutral level. (Newswires)

BoJ board member Sakurai says it’s too early to mull withdrawal of stimulus and now is the time to watch data carefully; he adds all policy options must be looked at when considering modifying policy. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European bourses are currently positive (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) with the current outperformer, the IBEX (+0.5%). FTSE 100 (-0.1%) is currently the underperforming bourse amid GBP strength post- Retail Sales. Auto names are being hit by the US import probe, with names such as Daimler (-2.9%), BMW (-2.8%), Volkswagen (-2.8%) and Peugeot (-2.1%) affected negatively by this news. In the M&A scope, the touted Barclays/Standard Chartered merger is stated to have created a rift between Barclays’ chief executive and chairman. Elsewhere, for Smurfit Kappa, a group of shareholders at the co. have asked the company to enter into talks with International Paper. However, the Smurfit board later reaffirmed their position against the deal.

FX

FX markets thus far are trading in a more relaxed fashion compared to yesterday’s sizeable moves seen in the early stages of European trade. Most majors are sticking to their recent ranges with the USD back below 94.00 (DXY -0.2%) in the wake of yesterday’s FOMC minutes release which was perceived as a tad dovish and did little to change the current ‘gradual hikes’ backdrop, while it also indicated the Fed would tolerate inflation temporarily above 2% and that there was a range of views on how many rate hikes are required.

USD/JPY remains a key focus for the market with the JPY broadly firmer against its major peers (albeit off best levels) with the major pair sitting just above 109.50 after the move to the downside ran out of steam ahead of the 30DMA seen at 109.20.

Elsewhere, the EUR has also been a beneficiary from the softer USD with EUR/USD reclaiming the 1.1700 handle after yesterday’s data-inspired rout with traders mindful over today’s ECB minutes release which will look to see if the official account of proceedings corroborates with Draghi’s vague overview of proceedings which left investors unclear as to what the ECB actually discussed at the meeting.

GBP has reclaimed 1.3400 to the upside after an across the board beat for UK retail sales, allied with upward revisions for 3/4 metrics. As can often be the case for UK data, GBP caught a bid ahead of the figures before the official release confirmed what markets had suspected. Markets also chose to look through dour comments from the ONS stating that the underlying position for retail sales is still subdued despite Aprils bounce-back, longer term growth has slowed considerably. With just one more tier 1 release from the UK due this week (Q1 GDP secondary reading tomorrow), market focus will eventually return to Brexit talks with mixed messages once again coming from UK press and the government after government sources denied reports suggesting UK PM May was to ask the EU for a new transition period until 2023.

Elsewhere, NAFTA currencies will likely remain in vogue despite not seeing much in the way of a sustained reaction to news that the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232 which was seen as an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal.

Finally, the TRY has pared around half of its gains seen against the USD yesterday after the CBRT held an extraordinary meeting to evaluate recent developments in which it raised the Late Liquidity Window (the lending rate) by 300bps to 16.50%, while it added that it will use strong monetary tightening to support price stability. Given the price action in recent trade, it appears that markets still cast serious doubts over the autonomy of the CBRT and whether attempts to defy Erdogan will be sustainable in the long-term ahead of domestic elections next month.

FIXED INCOME

Fixed income markets have pulled back from their post-FOMC levels which were seen after treasuries caught a bid as traders modestly scaled back their expectations for 4 rate hikes this year. EU paper initially saw a choppy start to the session post-Eurex open before the complex gained traction to the downside following an across the board beat for UK retail sales which saw Gilts pressured before finding support just above the 122.00 level. In terms of the follow though for Bunds, the GE 10yr took out support seen at 159.50 before stopping shy of an hourly trend line around 159.40 as highlighted by IFR. Elsewhere across the continent, today’s session has seen some much needed reprieve for Italian paper with touted short-covering said to be behind the latest move with markets also likely taking comfort from reports that the 5SM could turn towards a potentially more market-friendly finance minister appointment with Zingales said to be in the running.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are mixed as markets focus on US President Trump’s protectionist policies. WTI crude (-0.7%) and Brent (-0.8%) continue to extend losses alongside the lacklustre risk tone and following the prior day’s surprise DoE crude inventory build. Expectations that OPEC could boost output to offset the supply disruptions caused by Iran and Venezuela remain on traders’ minds. Meanwhile, gold (+0.5%) continues to creep higher as the yellow metal tracks the softer dollar. Elsewhere, Shanghai copper prices snapped a five-day winning streak and closed lower amid Trump stating that any deal with China will “need a different structure”. On the flip side, Chinese steel and iron ore futures closed higher, snapping its 7-day losing streak.

Russian Energy Novak says that gradual oil output recovery will be discussed in June. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

24th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded subdued with Trump’s trade policies returning to the forefront of attention after the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232, while reports also noted that tariffs of as much as 25% are being considered and is likely an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal. In addition, increasing uncertainty whether the US-North Korea summit will take place added to dampened tone, which in turn has collectively overshadowed a slightly-dovish perceived FOMC minutes. Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) was the underperformer as currency strength sapped exporter sentiment and with automakers reeling from the prospects of the hefty import duties, while ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by financials amid the ongoing banking royal commission grilling on the sector, although broader losses in the index were stemmed by strength in consumer stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (Unch.) traded indecisive following a net neutral liquidity operation by the PBoC and mixed signals on trade talks from President Trump who stated discussions are moving along nicely, but then suggested a change in the structure may be needed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the underperformance seen in Japanese stocks, as prices took a breather from the prior day’s gains and with weaker demand seen in today’s enhanced-liquidity auction for 10yr-30yr JGBs.

FTSE

Paddy Power Betfair (PPB LN) – Co. reportedly has agreed to buy US fantasy sports site FanDuel for USD 158mln. (Axios)

Glencore (GLEN LN) - UC Rusal restarts shipments of aluminium to some customers; according to sources. (Newswires)

Smurfit Kappa (SKG LN) – A group of shareholders at the co. have asked the company to enter into talks with International Paper. (Newswires)

Babcock (BAB LN) / BAE Systems (BA/ LN) – Babcock is in talks with BAE and other companies about a potential joint bid to build a British naval vessel, a tender worth up to GBP 1bln. (FT)

Barclays (BARC LN) – A rift has arisen between Co. chief executive and chairman following speculations that the Co. is considering a bid for Standard Chartered (STAN LN) to merge the two companies, creating a company worth over GBP 60bln. (The Times)

GSK (GSK LN) – Source reports suggest that the Co. has concerns over its potential sales of its Horlicks brand as the deal could incur a tax liability of 40%. As such, the Co. now intends to find an acquirer that would merge with the Co.’s Consumer Healthcare unit and carry out a share swap. (Newswires)

EX-DIVS: Bunzl Plc (BNZL LN), Carnival Plc (CCL LN), DCC Plc (DCC LN), Imperial Brands Plc (IMB LN), WM Morrison Supermarkets Plc (MRW LN) and Whitbread Plc (WTB LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 3.2 points off the FTSE 100

OTHER UK COMPANIES

TalkTalk (TALK LN) – The co. has sold a part of its B2B business customer base to the Daisy Group for GBP 175mln. (Sky News)

BROKER MOVES

ABF (ABF LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – Reiterates guidance through to 2021, say revenues to grow 1-2% per year from 2017-21, adj. EBITDA to grow by 2-4% and free cash flow by 10% per year through 2021, considering share buyback. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The co have said they will contribute to a decrease in leverage exposure in the corporate and investment bank of over EUR 100bln, in prime finance by ~EUR 50bln, will reduce headcount in equities by 25% and to reduce adj. costs to EUR 22bln in 2019. Reaffirms target of post-tax return on tangible equity of ~10%.(Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – CEO’s position is more unstable than ever as he is preparing to unveil a new strategy to satisfy impatient investors including Sweden’s Cevian and activist investor Elliott, according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BASF (BAS GY) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUALWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

COMMERZBANK (CBK GY) DOWNGRADED TO EQUALWEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

PAN EUROPE

Auto Names - US President Trump confirmed he instructed the Commerce Department to consider an investigation on auto imports. (Newswires)

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co. division and the global leader in biosimilars Sandoz has received European Commission approval for Zessly (infliximab) use in Europe for rheumatoid arthritis, adult Crohn's disease, paediatric Crohn's disease, adult ulcerative colitis, paediatric ulcerative colitis, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis and plaque psoriasis. (Novartis)

US

The overnight risk-off tone weighed on US equity futures, with the ES basing around 2705 in pre-market trade. At the cash open, however, there was a convergence with cash indices (ES rallied slightly, while SPX sold off), and ES was trading horizontally around 2710-2715. In wake of the FOMC meeting minutes, however, the Emini rallied towards the familiar 2730 area, with the minutes revealing little by way of new information, and was consistent with gradual hikes. subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: FOMC Minutes stated that most felt it would soon be appropriate to raise rates again if outlook remained intact. Minutes contained little that changes the current ‘gradual hikes’ script
content:
FOMC Minutes stated that most felt it would soon be appropriate to raise rates again if outlook remained intact. Minutes contained little that changes the current ‘gradual hikes’ script

Asian equity markets traded subdued after US President Trump ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports

Looking ahead, highlights include German GDP, UK retail sales, ECB minutes and a slew of central bank speakers

FOMC

FOMC Minutes stated that most felt it would soon be appropriate to raise rates again if outlook remained intact and many also saw little evidence of labour market overheating with wage pressures still moderate.

The minutes also stated there was a range of views on how many rate hikes are required and that few noted the FFR could reach neutral level before too long if rate hikes continued.

Furthermore, it was suggested that a modest overshoot of inflation could be helpful and signalled the Fed would tolerate inflation temporarily overshooting 2%. (Newswires)

The reaction across US asset classes was initially modest as the comments didn’t shed too much light on how many further rate hikes there will be in 2018, with a range of views evident. However, USD was gradually sold after the release, Treasuries caught a bid, and equity futures climbed as sentiment reflected that the minutes contained little that changes the current ‘gradual hikes’ script. The result was that money markets’ pricing of the Fed’s rate hike trajectory also eased slightly; while the probability of a June hike still remains in the 90s and the probability of two additional hikes this year slipped to under 90%, while the probability of four hikes declined by around 10ppts to about 41%.
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded subdued with Trump’s trade policies returning to the forefront of attention after the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232, while reports also noted that tariffs of as much as 25% are being considered and is likely an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal. In addition, increasing uncertainty whether the US-North Korea summit will take place added to dampened tone, which in turn has collectively overshadowed a slightly-dovish perceived FOMC minutes. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (Unch.) traded indecisive following a net neutral liquidity operation by the PBoC and mixed signals on trade talks from President Trump who stated discussions are moving along nicely, but then suggested a change in the structure may be needed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the underperformance seen in Japanese stocks, as prices took a breather from the prior day’s gains and with weaker demand seen in today’s enhanced-liquidity auction for 10yr-30yr JGBs.

China Mofcom said it will encourage companies to import more from US and that it welcomes US sending officials to China, although it reiterated that China has not promised to reduce trade deficit by a certain amount and will unswervingly protect its interests. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3816 (Prev. 6.3773)

Bank of Korea kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected, via unanimous decision. BoK stated that domestic growth is on foreseen path and that exports will sustain expansion, but also noted job growth slowed and that growth of household debt has exceeded the pace seen in past years. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May is to ask EU for a new Brexit transition to last until 2023 to avoid a hard border (Times)

UK Brexit negotiators did not present the Irish Backstop plan in this week's Brexit negotiations, according to sources. (Newswires) In separate news, HMRC stated that UK business could take a GBP 20bln hit from the post-Brexit customs model advocated by Brexiteers in the Cabinet including Johnson, Gove and Fox. (Guardian)

Italian President Mattarella gave the PM mandate to candidate Conte who will begin talks with party leaders on Thursday, while there were also comments from Conte that his government will be one of change and added they are to be aware of the need to confirm European and international obligations. (Newswires/ANSA)


FX

In FX markets, the DXY gradually slipped below the 94.00 level in the wake of the FOMC minutes which was perceived as a tad dovish. Elsewhere, GBP/USD was marginally supported following reports PM May is to ask the EU for a new Brexit transition to last until 2023 to avoid a hard border, while JPY continued to outperform on safe-haven demand with USD/JPY extending its retreat below the 110.00 handle. TRY remained firmer overnight with USD/TRY below 4.6000 after the Turkish Central Bank finally stepped in to support the currency and hiked the lending rate by 300bps in an extraordinary meeting.

New Zealand Trade Balance (Apr) M/M 263.0M vs. Exp. 198.0M (Prev. -86.0M, Rev. -156.0M). (Newswires)
New Zealand Exports (Apr) 5.05B vs. Exp. 4.85B (Prev. 4.85B, Rev. 4.79B)
New Zealand Imports (Apr) 4.79B vs. Exp. 4.65B (Prev. 4.94B, Rev. 4.95B)

Turkish Central Bank held an extraordinary meeting to evaluate recent developments in which it raised the Late Liquidity Window (the lending rate) by 300bps to 16.50%, while it added that it will use strong monetary tightening to support price stability. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively uneventful overnight as markets focused on a slew of macro risk factor including the FOMC and Trump’s protectionist policies. Nonetheless, WTI crude languished below the USD 72.00/bbl alongside the lacklustre risk tone and following the prior day’s surprise DoE crude inventory build. Elsewhere, gold saw marginal gains amid a weaker greenback post-FOMC minutes.


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he will know by next week if the summit with North Korea on June 12th will go ahead. In related news, North Korea said it condemns comments from US Vice-President Pence that North Korea may end up like Libya, while a Foreign Ministry official stated they will suggest to North Korea’s leadership to reconsider summit and that summit is entirely up to Washington. (Nikkei/KCNA)

North Korea is likely to demolish its nuclear test site later today. (Yonhap)

US Secretary of State Pompeo is said to be seeking a meeting with allies including Europe in early or mid-June to resolve nuclear deal issues. (Newswires)

Iran’s Supreme Leader set 7 conditions for European countries if they want Tehran to remain in the nuclear deal and said Europe must promise it will not seek negotiations over Iran’s missile programme and regional activities. Furthermore, the Supreme Leader also called on atomic energy officials to be prepared to resume suspended nuclear activities if necessary. (Newswires)

US Ambassador to Israel said the White House Middle East peace plan could be unveiled within next few months. (Newswires)

US expelled 2 Venezuelan diplomats in which they were ordered to leave in 48 hours. (Newswires)


US

The Treasury complex was bid as US traders got to their desks as risk sentiment slumped after Asia-Pac trade though picked up after the Turkish Central Bank surprisingly hiked rates. After the FOMC minutes, Treasuries rallied once again with futures hitting session highs as the Fed hiking trajectory eased slightly for 2018. The front and belly of the curve lead the moves with 5yr and 10yr yields higher by c.6bps. 5s30s and 10s3s widened by c.3bps whilst 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c.2bps. US auction of 5-year debt was on the screws, with the stop-out rate the highest since 2008. Internals were also fair, with cover coming in above recent averages. However, the internal takedown was below the prior and recent averages, and that left dealers with their highest takedown since December 2017. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 10 ticks higher at 118-28.

US President Trump instructed the Commerce Department to consider Section 232 trade investigation on auto imports for national security purposes, while reports also noted that the Trump administration is considering a plan that would impose new tariffs of as much as 25% on imported vehicles. (Newswires/WSJ)

US President Trump said Mexico and Canada have been very difficult in NAFTA negotiations. In related news, Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland stated that NAFTA engagement continues at a very intense level and that significant progress was made on autos, while Mexico NAFTA negotiator said a skinny NAFTA deal is not an option and that they are not interested in a partial agreement. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia trade mostly subdued as prospects of Trump auto tariffs and uncertainty of US-North Korea summit overshadows somewhat dovish FOMC minutes
content: Asia equity markets traded subdued with Trump’s trade policies returning to the forefront of attention after the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232, while reports also noted that tariffs of as much as 25% are being considered and is likely an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal. In addition, increasing uncertainty whether the US-North Korea summit will take place added to dampened tone, which in turn has collectively overshadowed a slightly-dovish perceived FOMC minutes. Nikkei 225 (-1.3%) was the underperformer as currency strength sapped exporter sentiment and with automakers reeling from the prospects of the hefty import duties, while ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by financials amid the ongoing banking royal commission grilling on the sector, although broader losses in the index were stemmed by strength in consumer stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) and Hang Seng (Unch.) traded indecisive following a net neutral liquidity operation by the PBoC and mixed signals on trade talks from President Trump who stated discussions are moving along nicely, but then suggested a change in the structure may be needed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat despite the underperformance seen in Japanese stocks, as prices took a breather from the prior day’s gains and with weaker demand seen in today’s enhanced-liquidity auction for 10yr-30yr JGBs.

subject: Philippines Central Bank Governor Espenilla says further decline in FX reserves will not hurt economy
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks are a tad subdued and Nikkei 225 underperforms on potential Trump tariffs for autos
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly negative with Trump’s trade policies returning to the forefront after the US President ordered the Commerce Department to consider a probe on auto imports for national security purposes under Section 232, while reports also noted that tariffs of as much as 25% are being considered and is likely an attempt to prod NAFTA counterparts for a better deal. In addition, increasing uncertainty whether the US-North Korea summit will take place has also added to dampened tone, which in turn has collectively overshadowed a slightly-dovish perceived FOMC minutes. Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) is the underperformer as currency strength saps exporter sentiment and with automakers reeling from the prospects of the hefty import duties, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) is led lower by financials amid the ongoing banking royal commission grilling on the sector, although broader losses in the index are stemmed by strength in consumer stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (+0.4%) are indecisive following a net neutral liquidity operation by the PBoC and mixed signals on trade talks from President Trump who stated discussions are moving along nicely, but then suggested a change in the structure may be needed.

In FX markets, the DXY gradually slipped below the 94.00 level in the wake of the FOMC minutes which was perceived as a tad dovish and did little to change the current ‘gradual hikes’ backdrop, while it also indicated the Fed would tolerate inflation temporarily above 2% and that there was a range of views on how many rate hikes are required. Elsewhere, GBP/USD is marginally higher with support seen following reports PM May is to ask the EU for a new Brexit transition to last until 2023 to avoid a hard border, while JPY continues to outperform on safe-haven demand with USD/JPY extending its retreat below the 110.00 handle.

Finally, 10yr JGBs trade flat despite the underperformance seen in Japanese stocks, as prices take a breather from the prior day’s gains and with an enhanced-liquidity auction for 10yr-30yr JGBs scheduled later.
